title: Pressure at Barcelona was FAR higher than it is here, insists 'cracking' Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola
text:
Sport Pressure at Barcelona was FAR higher than it is here, insists 'cracking' Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola The Spaniard is being questioned as his Blues struggle to match the endless success he enjoyed in Spain and with Bayern Munich but he says he just needs time Share Guardiola is frustrated, but dismissed the idea he's under more pressure than ever before (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The good news about Manchester City , according to Pep Guardiola , is that managing here is a doddle compared to the intense spotlight of Barcelona. 
The bad news? 
Northern England’s biting wind is not good for “old people” like him! 
He may not have given the impression in a grumpy post-match interview after the win over Burnley on Monday – when he complained about virtually every aspect of Premier League football – but the Spanish coach insists the demands when he was in charge at the Nou Camp were much tougher. 
Guardiola has not set English football alight so far, and has reacted tetchily to the increasingly severe criticism surrounding City’s indifferent form, but insists he is NOT struggling with the strain. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Is Pep Guardiola feeling the strain? Share this video Watch Next 
“More pressure here? No. The most pressure was in Barcelona,” he said. 
“You cannot compare the pressure in Barcelona and Madrid to Munich or Manchester. Here it is less, much, much less.” 
His interviews after the Burnley game suggested Guardiola is feeling the heat. 
But he opened up on City’s hopes, dreams and future to American TV station NBC. 
There, he hinted that City don’t have the expectation of the likes of Barca, or even rivals Manchester United, because they don’t have the history, and it will take time for him to make them a top club. (Photo: AFP/Getty) ...during a 4-2 thrashing away to struggling champions Leicester (Photo: Getty) Read More Conte gives fellow rookie Guardiola sound advice on adjusting to the Premier League 
“For the way they play, for the unpredictable things you cannot control, I will need more time to achieve what I want,” he said. “When I came here, people expected a lot of things from me and my staff because we won a lot of prizes in the past. 
“But the best football I played at Barcelona was the last year — much better than when we won the Treble or when we won six trophies in a row. [And] My last year at Bayern Munich was much, much better than my first. 
“So here, the last day I will be manager, I will be better than now. Read More The New Year's Eve loss at Liverpool had Guardiola scratching his head... (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) ...looking like he didn't know how to fix what was going wrong... (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) ...and consoling his beaten team at the final whistle (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Read More "Rebellion, rejection and regret" — Body language expert's verdict THAT interview 
"You need to make mistakes, to understand many things. I know I don’t have time but I will try.” 
Despite Guardiola’s frustration in recent weeks, he is convinced his philosophy will be successful once his players buy into it fully. 
The 45-year-old said: “Sometimes you win, ­sometimes not. 
"But I have to try to convince them, on the training ground, in the private one-to-one meetings and group meetings, that we are together. I try to convince them because I feel it is the better way to win games.
